After looking into this some more, I have found that there is  
speciation =
code amidst in the reproduction

On Mar 6, 2010, at 4:16 PM, Daniel Tuohy <=
danielr2e@...> wrote:

> [Attachment(s) from Daniel Tuohy included be=
low]
> Hello,
>
>
> My refactoring of JNeat has brought me to the speciatio=
n code, and  
> I'm finding it tricky to reconcile the JNeat speciation cod=
e with  
> descriptions in NEAT papers and discussion in this forum.  There=
 is  
> a lot going on here, but I think I can state the problem simply  
>=
 without getting into the details of the JNeat code.
>
> Ken's paper descri=
bes speciation as occuring every generation.   
> Speciation entails iterat=
ing over the population, and performing  
> some rudimentary clustering usi=
ng a compatibility function and  
> threshhold.  Pretty straightforward.
>
=
> Indeed, this algorithm is implemented in JNeat as the speciate()  
> meth=
od, but its only invoked at the beginning of evolution and never  
> again!=
  The growth and death of species afterwards is determined by  
> some code=
 in the epoch() method that does not appear to resemble  
> NEAT speciation=
.  I'm concerned that whatever JNeat is doing, it  
> isn't what Ken had in=
 mind, and it leads to some strange behavior.   
> Attached is a graph show=
ing how the number of species grows during a  
> run of the XOR experiment.=
  With a population size of 500, it  
> increases almost monotonically to 4=
00 before leveling off after 40  
> generations.
>
> Shouldn't the speciate=
() method be called after ever generation/ 
> epoch?  Isn't this way too ma=
ny species?  Approximately how many  
> species would you expect for the XO=
R experiment with 500 individuals?
>
>
> Regards,
> Daniel
> 

--Apple-Mail-3--226473146

<html><body bgcolor=3D"#FFFFFF"><div>After looking into this some more, I h=
ave found that there is speciation code amidst in the reproduction <br=
><br>On Mar 6, 2010, at 4:16 PM, Daniel Tuohy <<a href=3D"mailto:danielr=
2e@...">danielr2e@...</a>> wrote:<br><br></div><div></div><b=
lockquote type=3D"cite"><div>




<span style=3D"display:none"> </span=
>



    <div id=3D"ygrp-text">
      
              
      
      <p>Hello=
,</p><div><br></div><div>My refactoring of JNeat has brought me to the spec=
iation code, and I'm finding it tricky to reconcile the JNeat speciation co=
de with descriptions in NEAT papers and discussion in this forum.  The=
re is a lot going on here, but I think I can state the problem simply witho=
ut getting into the details of the JNeat code.  </div>

<div><br></div=
><div>Ken's paper describes speciation as occuring every generation.  =
Speciation entails iterating over the population, and performing some rudim=
entary clustering using a compatibility function and threshhold.  Pret=
ty straightforward.</div>

<div><br></div><div>Indeed, this algorithm is im=
plemented in JNeat as the speciate() method, but its only invoked at the be=
ginning of evolution and never again!  The growth and death of species=
 afterwards is determined by some code in the epoch() method that does not =
appear to resemble NEAT speciation.  I'm concerned that whatever JNeat=
 is doing, it isn't what Ken had in mind, and it leads to some strange beha=
vior.  Attached is a graph showing how the number of species grows dur=
ing a run of the XOR experiment.  With a population size of 500, it in=
creases almost monotonically to 400 before leveling off after 40 generation=
s.  </div>

<div><br></div><div>Shouldn't the speciate() method be cal=
led after ever generation/epoch?  Isn't this way too many species? &nb=
sp;Approximately how many species would you expect for the XOR experiment w=
ith 500 individuals?</div>

<div><br></div><div><br></div><div>Regards,</di=
v><div>Daniel</div>
<p></p>

    </div>
     

    





<!-- end group ema=
il -->

</div></blockquote></body></html>
